docs.lead_paragraph: AT FORD, BAD GETS WORSE -- The Ford Motor Company reported its worst financial results in more than 14 years and warned that its business was likely to worsen in the months ahead. Its new chief executive, Alan R. Mulally, said the automaker would require a full transformation in the way it thought about consumers and approached the American market. [Page A1.] HUMANE GROCERIES -- Whole Foods is preparing to roll out a line of meat products that will carry labels saying ''animal compassionate,'' indicating the animals were raised in a humane manner until they were slaughtered. [A1.] GOOGLE OFFERS TAILORED SEARCH --Google unveiled a tool that allows Web sites and blogs to offer visitors a customized version of its search engine, narrowing down its vast index so the results are more relevant for the sites' users. [C3.] INDICATORS LITTLE HELP TO G.O.P. -- Economic indicators are looking up, with gas prices tumbling, unemployment falling to its lowest level in more than five years, and the Dow Jones industrial index setting records almost daily. Yet Republican candidates do not seem to be getting any traction from them in the midterm elections just two weeks away. [C1.] I.B.M. SUES AMAZON OVER PATENTS -- I.B.M. filed two lawsuits against Amazon.com, contending the big online retailer has built its business on technology developed by I.B.M. [C1.] LENDERS COURT UNIVERSITIES -- With rising tuition and lagging government aid making private student loans a big and increasingly competitive business, lenders are courting universities with trips and gifts in hopes that they will steer students their way. [A1.] COURT RULES AGAINST THE TIMES -- A federal magistrate judge ordered The New York Times to disclose the identities of three confidential sources used by one of its columnists, Nicholas Kristof, in writing about the investigation of the deadly anthrax mailings of 2001. [A21.] AIDS AND LEPROSY LINKED -- With affordable AIDS drugs arriving in many poor countries, experts say a startling and worrisome side effect has emerged: in some patients, the treatment uncovers a hidden leprosy infection. [F1.] CITY CRACKS DOWN ON PIRACY -- Seeking to crack down on the sometimes-violent world of video piracy, New York City is beginning an aggressive campaign to hold building owners liable for illegal distribution activities on their property and to make the recording of movies in theaters a crime. [B4.] COKE BACKS CIVIL RIGHTS MUSEUM -- Coca-Cola said it would donate two and a half acres of prime land near Atlanta's downtown tourist district to a proposed civil rights museum that would hold, among other exhibits, the papers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. [A17.] POPULATION MARKETING -- In an era of rancorous debates about overpopulation and immigration, only a few marketers are paying attention to a major promotional opportunity that occurred last week when, according to the Census Bureau, the population of the United States reached 300 million. Advertising. [C3.] OUTSIDER TO HEAD WRIGLEY -- The Wm. Wrigley Jr. Company named William D. Perez chief executive, the first time it has tapped someone outside its founding family in 115 years. The appointment puts Mr. Perez, left, in a position similar to his last one at Nike, where the founder promised to stay out of the way, then pushed him out after only 13 months. [C1.] STOCKS CONTINUE RALLY -- Wall Street extended its rally as investors grew more confident about earnings reports and as a decline in oil bolstered hopes for consumer spending. [C11.] AT&T PROFIT UP SHARPLY -- AT&T reported that its profit increased 74 percent in the third quarter, spurred by strong growth at Cingular Wireless and savings from the merger of the old AT&T and SBC Communications. [C11.] RUSSIAN CELLPHONE INQUIRY -- In the latest chapter in the tale of 167,000 missing Motorola cellphones in Russia, Moscow prosecutors say they are investigating whether 30,000 that were supposedly destroyed were, in fact, sold at low prices in the Russianh provinces. [C11.] ONLINE Business Briefing Articles on these developments are at nytimes.com/business. XEROX said quarterly earnings rose to $536 million, aided by a tax refund and strong sales of color machines and supplies for commercial and office use. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) SAKS INC., owner of the Saks Fifth Avenue department stores, said its chief financial officer, Douglas Coltharp, and two other executives would resign next year as the company consolidates operations to New York City. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) THE UNITED STATES has requested that Namibia extradite the former chief executive of Comverse Technology, Jacob Alexander, who is accused of a scheme to pocket millions of dollars by secretly manipulating stock options, an American Embassy spokesman said. (AP) MEDCO HEALTH SOLUTIONS, a manager of employee prescription drug benefits, agreed to pay $155 million to settle allegations that it accepted kickbacks from drug makers and submitted false claims to the government. (BLOOMBERG NEWS) A FORMER printing-plant employee admitted leaking copies of the ''Inside Wall Street'' column from Business Week magazine as part of a guilty plea to insider trading charges yesterday in a case that the authorities have cited as a sprawling illegal stock-trading scheme. (AP) THE HOUSING SLUMP was a heavy burden for the economy in the late summer, a top adviser to President Bush said. (AP)
